G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 28, authorizes this Court to modify custody and parenting‑time provisions upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and a showing that modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting time pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the prior custody judgment issued by this Court on May 15, 2019.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Barnstable Probate and Family Court because the existing judgment was issued in this Division and the child has significant connections to this jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: Venue is proper in the Barnstable Probate and Family Court because the existing judgment was issued in this Division and the child has significant connections to this jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 31, provides that in awarding or modifying custody, the rights of the parents shall be held equal, and the happiness and welfare of the child shall determine custody and parenting time.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody or parenting‑time order may be modified where there has been a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child and where modification is in the child’s best interest.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case discusses, but expressly declines to apply, the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard that governs modification proceedings under G.L. c. 209C, § 20. Instead, it treats the matter as an initial custody determination under the ‘best interests of the child’ standard in § 10(a) and notes that the modification standard was waived and not before the court. Therefore, it does not itself establish or apply the Massachusetts rule for modifying existing custody or parenting‑time orders, even though it briefly describes § 20 in passing.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … General Laws c. 209C, § 20, gives the Probate Court jurisdiction to modify an existing judgment for support, custody, or visitation. Such a modification should be made only if ‘a substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child has occurred.’”}

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody or parenting‑time order may be modified where there has been a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child and where modification is in the child’s best interest.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the statutory standard under G.L. c. 208, § 28, that a custody judgment may be modified only upon a finding of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the modification must be necessary in the child’s best interests. The court reverses because those requirements were not met, thereby affirming the rule that both elements—material and substantial change plus best interests—are prerequisites to modifying custody or parenting-time orders.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.proposition: In any matter involving custody or parenting time, the paramount consideration is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly frames the custody determination around the “best interests of the child,” and discusses how domestic violence must be evaluated because of its impact on those best interests. However, the excerpt provided does not contain a canonical, formulaic statement that in all custody or parenting time matters the paramount consideration is the child’s best interests; that principle is applied rather than expressly re-articulated in those words. Thus the case is consistent with and supportive of the proposition, though not as a clean quotable rule statement in this excerpt.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.relevant_excerpt:
The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. ... The Appeals Court gave great weight to this court’s Gender Bias Study ... and particularly to the recommendation in that study that,

"The legislature and/or appellate courts should make it clear that abuse of any family member affects other family members and must be considered in determining the best interests of the child in connection with any order concerning custody."

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.raw_text: Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 243–244 (2000)
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.proposition: The best‑interest determination is fact‑specific and considers the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs, stability, continuity, and the capacity of the parents to meet those needs.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that custody orders under G.L. c. 209C are based on the best interests of the child and that the judge may consider any factors pertinent to those interests, including present and probable future welfare. The court affirms that the trial judge properly weighed a wide range of fact‑specific considerations about the child’s welfare—caregiving quality, structure, stimulation and enrichment, parental judgment, and each parent’s capacity to meet the child’s needs. This aligns with the proposition that best‑interest determinations are fact‑specific and encompass the child’s emotional, physical, developmental needs, stability, continuity, and parental capacity.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.relevant_excerpt: “‘[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .’ … and a judge may consider any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the dispute. … ‘It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the child[] in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future . . . .’ … [T]he judge’s voluminous findings demonstrate consideration of myriad factors and circumstances relevant to the child’s best interests….”

Custody of a Minor, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 40.raw_text: Custody of a Minor, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 402, 407–08 (1988)
Custody of a Minor, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 40.proposition: Stability and continuity in a child’s schooling, sleep, and daily routine are central components of the best‑interest analysis.

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 224\u20.proposition: Stability and continuity in a child’s schooling, sleep, and daily routine are central components of the best‑interest analysis.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 224\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion certainly recognizes that stability in a child’s life is important and that Hugo needs a “consistent and predictable” environment, but it does not frame stability and continuity in schooling, sleep, and daily routine as central or dispositive components of the best‑interest analysis. Rather, the court treats stability as one factor to be weighed against others (such as the aunt’s superior capacity to address Hugo’s developmental needs) and explicitly rejects creating presumptions based on current placement stability. Thus, the case does not establish the proposition that such day‑to‑day stability is central to the best‑interest inquiry.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 224\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Stability in the life of a child, especially one as young as Hugo, is important, as the judge himself recognized. Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 617 (1986). Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.”

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146, 151–52 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.proposition: Courts in Massachusetts recognize that a substantial change in a parent’s residence and the resulting travel burdens may justify modifying parenting time to protect a child’s best interests.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal case focused on whether the custodial mother may relocate the children to California under the Yannas real-advantage/best-interests test. While the court repeatedly considers the impact of a "cross-country" or "bicoastal" existence and the effect on the father’s substantial parenting time, it does so in the context of deciding whether to permit removal at all, not whether to modify parenting time in response to a relocation. The case does not involve or decide a post-move modification of parenting time, nor does it frame the travel burdens as a basis for modifying parenting schedules; instead, those burdens are a reason to deny removal. Thus it does not support the proposition that Massachusetts courts modify parenting time because of substantial residence changes and travel burdens.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.relevant_excerpt: On the whole, the children spend nearly one-third of the year with the father. For these reasons, the judge found that a cross-country move would impose significant stress on the children and the father and negatively impact the frequency and quality of his parenting time with them. … The judge did not err in finding that the proposed move would have clear and significant negative effects on the children and the father that were not outweighed by the benefits that would inure to the mother.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: Courts in Massachusetts recognize that a substantial change in a parent’s residence and the resulting travel burdens may justify modifying parenting time to protect a child’s best interests.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The case concerns a removal/relocation request, not a post‑judgment modification of parenting time based on new travel burdens. The court discusses how to balance the custodial parent’s relocation interests with the child’s best interests and the noncustodial parent’s visitation rights, but it does not frame the issue as modifying an existing parenting schedule in response to a substantial change of residence. Thus, it is authority on relocation standards and best‑interests analysis, not specifically on modification of parenting time due to travel burdens.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent … The reasonableness of alternative visitation arrangements should be assessed.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: While it is important to maintain a meaningful relationship between Father and Sophie, that relationship should be fostered in a manner that does not impose excessive travel or interfere with the child’s education and health.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody and visitation generally in terms of the children’s best interests and approves a reduction in the father’s visitation time because of parental conflict and some problematic conduct, but it does not address issues of excessive travel, interference with schooling, or health-related travel burdens. The quoted portions simply uphold judicial discretion to limit visitation to promote the children’s best interests, not the specific principle that the parent–child relationship must be fostered in a way that avoids excessive travel or disruption of education and health. Accordingly, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order. … ‘[T]he “best interests” of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’ Felton v. Felton, supra at 233.”

Boucher v. Boucher, 403 Mass. 1002 (1988.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and Massachusetts case law, when a material change in circumstances arises, the Court “may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care, custody, and maintenance of the minor children” if required in the child’s best interests.

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 543\u2.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and Massachusetts case law, when a material change in circumstances arises, the Court “may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care, custody, and maintenance of the minor children” if required in the child’s best interests.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 543\u2.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Smith v. McDonald is a concurrence focused on statutory interpretation of G.L. c. 209C in a paternity/relocation context, not on modification of prior custody judgments under G.L. c. 208, § 28. It does not discuss the material-change-in-circumstances standard or the court’s authority to modify an earlier judgment regarding care, custody, and maintenance of minor children. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific § 28 modification proposition cited.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 543\u2.relevant_excerpt: This is not a removal case, and Yannas is inapposite. Neither the judge nor the parties has cited to a single case, from any jurisdiction (and I am not aware of any from my own investigation), that gives a judge authority to pull a parent and child unwillingly back to a State where the parent had a prior and unilateral right to leave. The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts.
